docs.lead_paragraph: What Americans really think about Medicare: They like it. They don’t want to see it significantly changed. But they’re conscious of the federal deficit and willing to consider a number of strategies to reduce the gap, including raising taxes on high earners, spending less on foreign aid and overseas military commitments, and limiting tax deductions for large corporations. They’re even amenable to certain cost-cutting measures in Medicare itself.

headline.main: How Do You Feel About Medicare?

docs.abstract: Despite its expense, Medicare remains quite popular, researchers find.
docs.snippet: Despite its expense, Medicare remains quite popular, researchers find.

docs.lead_paragraph: REINWALD--Charles Anthony Age 85, passed away due to prostate cancer June 2, 2011. Charles lived in Scarsdale NY from 1964-2004, and then in Tequesta, Florida. Charles was born in 1925, in Flushing Queens, New York to the late Charles Anthony Reinwald, Sr. and Estella Mary Brake Reinwald. He leaves his wife of 49 years, Anne, and three children: Charles, Jr. and his wife Sarah, Lisa Silverman and her husband Robert, and Andrea Dabbar and her husband Paul, and a sister, Shirley R. Johnson, and five grandchildren: Andrew, David and Samantha Silverman, and William and Katherine Dabbar. Charles graduated Yale Univ. in 1946 from Navy officer training program, attending during World War II, and received a degree in history. He received a law degree from NYU Law School in 1949. He was an attorney with Allstate Insurance Co. When both he and his wife were diagnosed with cancer in 1999, he founded the Cancer Cure Coalition, dedicated to the cure and prevention of cancer. The coalition made efforts in patient advocacy including hosting a conference, and sponsored journalistic research. He continued his work with stock investing, surveying new cancer treatments and working on a book on cancer treatments, and managing the Cancer Cure Coalition as long as his health permitted. He participated in in local government and organizations including the Scarsdale American Legion, and the Masons. He participated in chess clubs and tournaments and attained the rank of chess master. He was an avid reader with broad interests. He occasionally attended meetings of the Religious Society of Friends. Charles is remembered as caring, genuine, and brilliant. He always had a smile and a story to tell.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINWALD, CHARLES A.

docs.lead_paragraph: A stream of hospital administrators, a state assemblyman, doctors and advocates for immigrants took the microphone at a sometimes raucous hearing in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday to plead with state officials not to close, merge or shrink troubled hospitals in the borough. The advocates identified at least 5 of the 17 hospitals in the borough -- those serving some of Brooklyn's poorest patients -- that they believe are endangered: Interfaith Medical Center, Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, Brooklyn Hospital Center, Wyckoff Heights Medical Center and Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center.

headline.main: Hospitals In Brooklyn Defended At Hearing

docs.abstract: Hospital administrators, doctors and advocates for immigrants plead with New York State officials at raucous hearing not to close, merge or shrink boroughs troubled hospitals; state officials will not confirm such plans, but make it clear they are looking for savings, suggesting that Brooklyn has too many hospital beds and that patients are using hospitals instead of appropriate outpatient clinics; photo (M)
